corpus.title: Welcome to Piazza!
corpus.body:
Piazza is a Q&A platform designed to get you great answers from classmates and instructors fast. We've put together this list of tips you might find handy as you get started:

 Ask questions!

The best way to get answers is to ask questions! Ask questions on Piazza rather than emailing your teaching staff so everyone can benefit from the response (and so you can get answers from classmates who are up as late as you are).

Edit questions and answers wiki-style.

Think of Piazza as a Q&A wiki for your class. Every question has just a single students' answer that students can edit collectively (and a single instructors’ answer for instructors).

 Add a followup to comment or ask further questions.

To comment on or ask further questions about a post, start a followup discussion. Mark it resolved when the issue has been addressed, and add any relevant information back into the Q&A above.

 Go anonymous.

Shy? No problem. You can always opt to post or edit anonymously.

 Tag your posts.

It's far more convenient to find all posts about your Homework 3 or Midterm 1 when the posts are tagged. Type a “#” before a key word to tag. Click a blue tag in a post or the question feed to filter for all posts that share that tag.

 Format code and equations.

Adding a code snippet? Click the pre or tt button in the question editor to add pre-formatted or inline teletype text. 
Mathematical equation? Click the Fx button to access the LaTeX editor to build a nicely formatted equation.

 View and download class details and resources. 

Click the Course Page button in your top bar to access the class syllabus, staff contact information, office hours details, and course resources—all in one place!


Contact the Piazza Team anytime with questions or comments at team@piazza.com. We love feedback!

corpus.title: When don't you want your code to be executable?
corpus.body: I was asked this question through email - "I am confused why you would sometimes wouldn't want to make a class executable."

responses.body: I am confused by the notion of a class being "executable". Does this mean the main method is inside of that particular class? What if you just wanted to have a class that stored a bunch of related methods and variables together in a container of sorts and then referenced them from the one that has the main method?

Sometimes you don't want your code to be executable when you are using say a class for data storage. EX: a dog class where the dog stores something like breed,color,age, etc... You don't want to execute the data storage but you do the usage of it. You will have a singe main method where the bulk of your "run" code is. Everything else is used to support the main method but only the main method is the "executable" part.

corpus.title: Using Ubuntu Terminal Windows App for Lab?
corpus.body: Dr. Hao, I was able to find an Ubuntu terminal app on the Windows Store that has the exact same functionality as the native terminal in Ubuntu. Would this be sufficient for completion of the lab or should I use a virtual machine instead?

responses.body: I encourage you to try, and you will soon discover its limitations (e.g., you can't transfer files from Windows to that mini Ubuntu system, or you can't start a 3rd-party text editor like Atom).

It's worth mentioning that VS Code, popular text editor similar to Atom, has an extension that allows opening the text editor remotely from within that Ubuntu subsystem. Once opened into a folder in Ubuntu, it functions just like it was running on Linux natively (same terminal and file access). Might be a handy workaround to the limitations of the system that Dr. Hao pointed out, although it will never be quite as good as running Linux proper.

corpus.title: Ran into a problem trying to dual boot Windows and Ubuntu
corpus.body:
Hello everyone,

As the title suggests, I'm wanting to dual boot my Windows operating system with Ubuntu. I have all the installations on my flashdrive and I was able to get to the Ubuntu trial menu. Now supposedly during the installation process there's supposed to be an option to run Ubuntu alongside Windows, but in my installation Ubuntu only gives me the options to erase Windows or to set the partitions myself. I'm not sure why the option won't show up, but I might assume it has to do with my hardrive storage. My OS (C:) has 1.8 TB of available space and 0.2 of that is used up by personal files (software, images, games, etc.). I was wondering if anyone has ever run into this issue before and was able to resolve the issue. If so, any advice would be greatly appreciated!

Thanks in advance, 

Isaiah

P.S. I'm in no rush to get this setup as I'm fine with using on-campus PCs to get my hw done if necessary, but I would like to get this resolved at some point.

responses.body:
I've tried to do the exact same thing you've done, and I also found that the only way to dual-boot Ubuntu with Windows is seemingly to set the partitions yourself. I found a guide that might help, it explains how to create each partition (root, swap and home). I haven't followed it all the way through, but you might find it useful.

https://itsfoss.com/install-ubuntu-1404-dual-boot-mode-windows-8-81-uefi/

UPDATE: I followed the tutorial to the end and my dual-boot of Ubuntu and Windows is working nicely.

UPDATE (by the author of this question): I followed the instructions above and it worked! One thing I would want to warn people about though. If you are like me, you'll have a Windows with UEFI secure boot and you'll need to turn it off to dual boot. When I disabled it, while I was able to use Ubuntu just fine, I was unable to access my Windows OS because it asked for a BitLocker recovery key (you get asked this for disabling secure boot). If you are NOT SURE where you have your BitLocker key ID, make sure you find it BEFORE you install Ubuntu, because if you are unable to find your recovery key, you will NOT br able to access your Windows OS. I luckly found it on my Microsoft account (on a seperate PC) and so I was fine, but for those of you who are unsure where to find your recovery key, go here:

https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/4026181/windows-10-find-my-bitlocker-recovery-key

And here:
https://youtu.be/AZlGZLDWnIQ

Hope this helps.

corpus.title: Lab2 clarifying rounding requirements

corpus.title: What does it mean to code a method?
corpus.body:
I received several questions on the method netPay of lab2, which are all relevant to your conceptual understanding of methods/functions. If you don't get it, you will meet more problems with lab3. I list the questions below and hope you can do some research on the questions while waiting for other capable students chime in:

Why do I need netPay method? I like to code everything in main method.Why do I need to write the calculation and printing codes for two times, both under netPay and in the main method? It seems redundant.Can I perform all my calculations in System.out.print("...")?My code seems to print everything as intended. Do I still need netPay method?Why do I need methods/functions anyway? What do they do?

responses.body:
Splitting logic into reusable methods has several benefits:

It drastically reduces duplicate code, thereby reducing file sizeIt makes errors easier to manage, since a problem with one method can be more easily isolated from the rest of the program and tested (this is how most of the tests on TravisCI work, as far as I can tell)
It can make the code easier to read as well, by splitting up the problem. You can have individual, small, methods that you can easily figure out what they do, rather than needing tons of comments or to figure out what the code is doing. This helps with figuring out errors too.
You don't need to know how a method is implemented in order to use it. Java itself includes hundreds of built-in methods that you can use without knowing the details of how they work on a system level (System.out.println(), String.equals(), Math.round(), etc.) This is called abstraction.

Make sure you are rounding to the 2nd decimal place. This is from the Lab 2 instructions. I'd take a look at "More problems with Travis CI" from earlier today.
Please note that every calculation needs to be rounded to the hundredth (2nd decimal place), including the calculation of gross payment, federal tax, state tax, social security, medicare, and net pay. You are expected to do some research and find how to do that on yourself.

corpus.title: Confused about how to implement replaceSingle without old character as parameter
corpus.body:
I am having trouble understanding how it's possible to replace a certain instance of a character within the input string if the old character is not passed as a parameter. On the appendix within the Google Doc for lab 3, it shows that the user entering the old character is necessary for the program to know what to replace. This brings me to my final question: how would you be able to find instances of the old character without being able to access it within the replaceSingle method? I'm a little confused here.

Also, there appears to be a disparity between the instructions for implementation of the replaceSingle method between the comments in the java file and on the Google Doc. In the java comments, it says the method should replace the character at a specified index with a new character, but on the Google Doc, it says the method should replace a specific instance of a specified character with another. I'm puzzled as to why there are two different descriptions of what the method should actually do.

responses.body:
There are other methods such as validateOccurance that will help you. I suggest you look at the skeleton for that method and it may help you determine how to implement your replaceSingle method.

From the description that comes with the method, it appears that the method is just supposed to take the character at index i and replace it with newChar. Determining that index i is something that will happen outside of the method. The Google Doc describes what the user-entered command "Replace Single" will do in the final product, which is not necessarily all taken care of in the replaceSingle() method, even though that would make sense.

I believe that it might have been a mistake because the description in the lab is different than the one on the code. I added the perameter for oldChar so that I could follow the description in the lab document

A question for you to think:
Should replaceSingle method take care of the tasks of finding the old character?

If you see any mismatch between Google Doc and Code Skeleton, stick to the instruction of Code Skeleton. In other words, do not change the parameters or method names.

My partner and I were naughty and changed the parameters for the time being. Our program exhibits the desired functionality anyways after we test replaceSingle in main. What would I need to do otherwise to avoid changing the parameters? Program a getOldChar function? Would that be less efficient?

corpus.title: Using Print Reverse multiple times
corpus.body:
I've made a printReverse function, and it can reverse a given string multiple times, but whenever I try to use it again, it prints out the reversed string instead of reversing back to the original one. I'm pretty sure I have to change my string variable to the new reversed string, but I'm not sure how to do that seeing as my function prints the reversed string but doesn't return it.

How would I retrieve my reversed string and make my original string variable equal to the reversed string?

Any help would be greatly appreciated.

responses.body:
If you look at the examples, the reversed string is never saved off. This is from Page 3 of the Lab 3 instructions
Enter the string to be manipulated
Co Dawgs!
Enter your command (quit, print reverse, replace all, replace single, remove)
print reverse
!sgwaD oC
Enter your command (quit, print reverse, replace all, replace single, remove)
replace single
skip a few lines, and then you the initial, unreversed string even though reverse string was only called once:
Your new sentence is: Go Dawgs!
Enter your command (quit, print reverse, replace all, replace single, remove)
quit
thus, you don't need to save off or retrieve the reversed string

corpus.title: Loop on error
corpus.body:
For lab3 the instructions say that a simple error message is sufficient if the user enters an invalid input. Would it be ok to have the user loop through their input until they enter a valid character/ input? In the appendix (pasted below) it shows the command being exited out of once the user enters an invalid int for the replaceSingle method, and so I'm wondering if that applies to every input.

Your new sentence is: Go Dawgs! 
Enter your command (quit, print reverse, replace all, replace single, remove) 
replace single 
Enter the character to replace 
g 
Enter the new character 
c 
Which g would you like to replace? 
2 
Error: the letter you are trying to replace does not exist 
Enter your command (quit, print reverse, replace all, replace single, remove) 
quit 
 

Intuitively I feel like having the user loop through until they enter something valid would create the best user interactions, but at the same time I'm not sure if it's allowed.

responses.body:
This interpretation is wrong:
In the appendix (pasted below) it shows the command being exited out of once the user enters an invalid int for the replaceSingle method
The sample interaction shows that there is supposed to b a loop:
Your new sentence is: Go Dawgs! 
Enter your command (quit, print reverse, replace all, replace single, remove) 
replace single 
Enter the character to replace 
g 
Enter the new character 
c 
Which g would you like to replace? 
2 
Error: the letter you are trying to replace does not exist 
Enter your command (quit, print reverse, replace all, replace single, remove) 
Let me know if you find this difficult to understand.

To clarify, by exit the command I mean how after the "Error: the letter you are trying to replace does not exist" it doesn't ask for a correct instance of g and rather starts a new command. Would it be ok to loop through asking for a correct int until the user enters a correct one instead of leaving the current command. For example:

Your new sentence is: Go Dawgs! 
Enter your command (quit, print reverse, replace all, replace single, remove) 
replace single 
Enter the character to replace 
g 
Enter the new character 
c 
Which g would you like to replace? 
2 
Error: the letter you are trying to replace does not exist

corpus.title: Scanner for Lab4?
corpus.body:
Hi,

In lab4 document it says, "Remember, your methods must work properly with any input we can provide, so test rigorously."

Does this mean that we are expected to test the methods in Lab4 using Scanner input, or is the input hard-coded in by the programmer?

responses.body:
Follow up question: how are we expected to test the Circle class without a main method? NoMain.PNG Having done OOP extensively in C++ before (unless Java is different), I have always tested my class using a main method. Does this infer that we create a separate file that handles the tests - a file that has main? 

Is the following link a good place to start? https://stackoverflow.com/questions/15173474/can-we-execute-a-java-program-without-a-main-method

Since the methods and constructors take objects and numeric data types as parameters and not Strings, I think we are just supposed to make sure that our code can handle all possible inputs given those types, like making sure a Circle never has a negative radius. We don't have to worry about the user inputting empty strings or invalid numbers because if someone did decide to use the Circle class with Scanner input, all of these issues would have to be handled before the input was converted to doubles and passed to these methods.

corpus.title: Need Help Rounding

responses.body:
This is what I did to round my values to three decimal places:
Math.round(num * 1000.0) / 1000.0

Using math.round on the number multiplied by 1000.0 and then dividing that result by 1000.0 seemed to do the trick. You can round to any number of decimal places by doing this with 10 to the power of however many decimal places you need (I used this strategy in lab 2, just with 100.0 so it would round to 2 decimal places).


To add on to this, the root problem of the code provided initially is that the number would be rounded to a whole integer every time, as you are only multiplying/dividing by 1000, not 1000.0. This can be fixed by either dividing by 1000.0, like above, or by type casting the Math.round operation to a double, as Math.round outputs an int by default.

corpus.title: Can we change method parameters? - Project 2
corpus.body:
Hey all, 
This is similar to a question that's already been asked for lab 5, but for project 2. I want to know if it's okay to change the method parameters for any of the given project 2 methods. It seems like I should be able to because the default parameters for "solveSudoku" is only the 2D array of characters, and I know I need some way to keep track of where I am in the board so adding extra parameters is the only solution that I can think of to do that. 

Thanks in advance,

Isaiah

responses.body: You aren't allowed to change the given method's parameters as I assume it messes with how the labs are graded, but you are allowed to create helper methods. With helper methods you could either overload the given methods or write a new method that does what you want, however you choose to solve your code.

You can always treat the given method as a wrapper method and set the inner method of yours to accept more parameters:

// wrapper methodpublic void givenMethod(int var) {   // inner method   myMethod(var, "a string")}private void myMethod(int var, String str) {  // do whatever I want}

corpus.title: What to Return for Empty Queues/Stacks
corpus.body:
For Lab 5, the instructions specifically say that, "this problem only needs to work in the scope of integers," which I take would mean any integer that's positive, negative, or zero, despite the example cases only including positive integers, (unless I'm mistaken).

If that's the case, I'm confused as to what pop(), top(), remove() and peek(), which are the methods affected by empty queues and stacks, are supposed to return to signify an empty queue/stack to the user, because they require that I return an int in all scenarios, and usual practices like -1 or 0 wouldn't be ideal here, because they could just be normal values.

I don't know if just printing something is enough for this or not, but I just wanna be sure.



Adding on to this, a normal stack will throw EmptyStackException when pop() or top() is used on an empty stack and a queue will throw NoSuchElementException when remove() is used on an empty queue. Are we to throw these same exceptions or just inform the user that their attempted action is invalid? An empty queue will return null when peek() is called on it, are we to return null as well?

responses.body:
This is a good question that you should try to answer in your code. See the lab instruction:
You may NOT assume that all operations are valid (for example, pop or peek operations might be called on an empty stack - how do you address such scenarios in your code?).
A hint on this: Can you recall some methods that we covered that can end the execution of a method abruptly, like System.exit()?

corpus.title: isParticallyValid
corpus.body:
Hey guys,

I was wondering why isParticallyValid takes two points for it's parameters when it seems like it'll work fine given only one point to check the row, column, and square?


Thanks!

Kirsten

responses.body:
You need to think that this method checks an area in the given 2D sudoku board. Using two points (top left corner and right bottom corner) is a conventional way to stand for an area, as it works for anything --- regardlessly if you are talking about a row, a column, or a square.

You can certainly use a number to stand for a row (i.e., row number), but this representation doesn't work for a square.

For this project, if you stick to the requirement of the parameters, the feedback you see from Travis may better help you, and it also makes our grading a little bit easier.

This made a lot more sense to me after I understood what "area" means in the comments in the code-- it refers to the area being checked, not the area of the whole board. So the (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) represent corners of whatever particle is being checked, whether it's a row column, or box.

corpus.title: Travis CI Directory Error
corpus.body:
Hello,

My team and I are getting this error that prevents us from compiling our Soduku.java code. Unless we are mistaken, it appears to be on Travis' end.

responses.body:
I built your project locally, and it is passing all of the tests. It looks like Travis is having some issue with gradle.

You can run the tests yourself by running the following command in the root of your repository:

./gradlew build --info
If you see BUILD SUCCESSFUL near the end of the input, then your program is passing all of the tests (this doesn't guarantee a perfect score, make sure to review the grading criteria for the project).
No worries about this. It will not have a negative impact on your grade. However, this is most likely due to that you corrupted the Gradle configurations and pushed those changes to Travis.

corpus.title: Welcome to Piazza!
corpus.body:
Piazza is a Q&A platform designed to get you great answers from classmates and instructors fast. We've put together this list of tips you might find handy as you get started:

 Ask questions!

The best way to get answers is to ask questions! Ask questions on Piazza rather than emailing your teaching staff so everyone can benefit from the response (and so you can get answers from classmates who are up as late as you are).

Edit questions and answers wiki-style.

Think of Piazza as a Q&A wiki for your class. Every question has just a single students' answer that students can edit collectively (and a single instructors’ answer for instructors).

 Add a followup to comment or ask further questions.

To comment on or ask further questions about a post, start a followup discussion. Mark it resolved when the issue has been addressed, and add any relevant information back into the Q&A above.

 Go anonymous.

Shy? No problem. You can always opt to post or edit anonymously.

 Tag your posts.

It's far more convenient to find all posts about your Homework 3 or Midterm 1 when the posts are tagged. Type a “#” before a key word to tag. Click a blue tag in a post or the question feed to filter for all posts that share that tag.

 Format code and equations.

Adding a code snippet? Click the pre or tt button in the question editor to add pre-formatted or inline teletype text. 
Mathematical equation? Click the Fx button to access the LaTeX editor to build a nicely formatted equation.

 View and download class details and resources. 

Click the Course Page button in your top bar to access the class syllabus, staff contact information, office hours details, and course resources—all in one place!


Contact the Piazza Team anytime with questions or comments at team@piazza.com. We love feedback!

corpus.title: Opening and closing scanner instances
corpus.body: Should we be opening and closing the instances of scanner around where we need them or just open one instance before we need it and close it at the very end of the program?

responses.body: You should only need one instance of Scanner. I’ve also heard that you can only open a Scanner object from System.in once in a program and can’t make another one once you’ve closed it. I cannot confirm if that is actually true but even if it isn’t, you should only have to open it once at the beginning of your program and end it when the program is terminated to prevent a resource leak.

corpus.title: working with objects when calling methods in other methods
corpus.body: I am having problems with the last method in lab 4, the intersect method. All my other methods work fine except I cant call my distance method inside my intersect method without getting a error. I have "Circle1.distance(Circle2)" however this results in "Circle1 cannot be resolved". This would be fixed if circle1 was made as a additional parameter however the lab only asks for one parameter. how do I directly refer to the object that this intersect method is working on (as in Circle1.intersect(Circle2) ) so calling the distance method can work? I've tried looking this up online for a day and a half and I haven't found anything close to my problem.

responses.body: Could I ask if have initialized/declared your circle1, or you literally just typed Circle1 without initializing/declaring it? Same for your circle2.

Circle 1 and 2 were objects created in the CircleTester.Java file, they were not declared or initialized in my Circle.java file (the class the objects were made from). circle 1 and 2 were the parameter names had for Circle AnotherCircle when I had two circle parameters and later figured out how to reduce it to one. There's no need to worry now however I received help from a friend and all I had to do was not state the first object in the method call, instead of having circle1.distance(circle2) I had to put distance(circle2) and the code now works as intended. apologies for the late response.

corpus.title: Welcome to Piazza!
corpus.body:
Piazza is a Q&A platform designed to get you great answers from classmates and instructors fast. We've put together this list of tips you might find handy as you get started:

 Ask questions!

The best way to get answers is to ask questions! Ask questions on Piazza rather than emailing your teaching staff so everyone can benefit from the response (and so you can get answers from classmates who are up as late as you are).

Edit questions and answers wiki-style.

Think of Piazza as a Q&A wiki for your class. Every question has just a single students' answer that students can edit collectively (and a single instructors’ answer for instructors).

 Add a followup to comment or ask further questions.

To comment on or ask further questions about a post, start a followup discussion. Mark it resolved when the issue has been addressed, and add any relevant information back into the Q&A above.

 Go anonymous.

Shy? No problem. You can always opt to post or edit anonymously.

 Tag your posts.

It's far more convenient to find all posts about your Homework 3 or Midterm 1 when the posts are tagged. Type a “#” before a key word to tag. Click a blue tag in a post or the question feed to filter for all posts that share that tag.

 Format code and equations.

Adding a code snippet? Click the pre or tt button in the question editor to add pre-formatted or inline teletype text. 
Mathematical equation? Click the Fx button to access the LaTeX editor to build a nicely formatted equation.

 View and download class details and resources. 

Click the Course Page button in your top bar to access the class syllabus, staff contact information, office hours details, and course resources—all in one place!


Contact the Piazza Team anytime with questions or comments at team@piazza.com. We love feedback!

responses.body:
Thank you Anna for posting this, I am also having the same problem with the “replace single”. I placed the string into a char array, but I am very lost in what my next steps should be.

-Blaine
Due date of lab2 is extended to 11:59 pm, Apr. 30th. I will talk about your challenge on Monday.
Thank you!

I have been asked this before, but I’ll place it here in written form, so others can use it if still needed.

Think of the problem in three steps. 

1) print a given string character by character, e.g., if the string is “Hello”, print “H”, “e”, “l”, etc.

2) think about how you would modified the the previous goal to just print out the “l” character.

3) now, just print out the second “l” character in the example string.

Once you can print the second “l”, you can modify it to replace that character instead of printing it. After that, you should have the framework to be able to replace a given character in a string.

corpus.title: Some Git Issues
corpus.body:
I was told that some of you run into the issues of "non-fast forward" and "dirty worktree" using Git.

If searching online [key words: non fast forward git eclipse], you will notice that many people run into this issue when using Git for their first time.

Here are some prior asked questions & answers on non-fast forward:

non-fast forward: https://git.eclipse.org/r/Documentation/error-non-fast-forward.htmlEgit rejected non-fast-forward: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/19474186/egit-rejected-non-fast-forwarddealing with non fast forward errors with git & eclipse: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PUZc-azvqI0

Here are some prior asked questions & answers on dirty worktree:
Eclipse/Git - Pull Failed Dirty Worktree: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/23599667/eclipse-git-pull-failed-dirty-worktreeEclipse: Resolve DIRTY_WORKTREE: http://openwritings.net/content/public/excerpt/eclipse-resolve-dirtyworktreeFailed, DIRTY_WORKTREE in eclipse, how to solve it?: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/23512578/failed-dirty-worktree-in-eclipse-how-to-solve-it?lq=1
Note that I found the easiest solution to dirty worktree is to save your code somewhere safe, and reset everything afterwards (i.e., delete what you have and download a new clean clone from GitHub)

Like why does

corpus.title: lab 3 Question - print statments
corpus.body:
In the instructions for the CircleTester program it says to display the center and radius using a "statement similar to previous println statements". Does this mean we have to modify the print statement? Can't we just use the same exact format?

I was wondering if this is correct, or if I am misunderstanding the instructions.
Thank you.

responses.body: You can use the same exact format. Thanks.

corpus.title: relationship between circleTester and Circle + function parameters
corpus.body:
This is probably too late to matter much but nevertheless I'm still confused and would like to figure it out for the future:

--I'm still confused on how functions in Circle are able to use objects from CircleTester. There's class objects in tester but how the functions in circle are able to use them is not as clear to me.

--the functions comparing two circles from circleTester would seem like it would need two variables as its parameters but it only needs one...
          --so how would you set up the comparison if only one is available to use?
             --how is the function taking in those parameters from tester?

I'm probably mixing a bunch of stuff up but maybe someone could lay it out clearer

responses.body:
There was no expectations for you to make CircleTester instances under Circle class. Could I ask which lines in the reading/java files confused you for this?

I don't think there are requirements for you to make functions under CircleTester comparing two circles. Instead, you are required to write an equals method under Circle class:
public boolean equals(Circle anotherCircle)
The above method takes only one parameter. The "Circle" is the data type specification. Could I ask which lines in the reading/java files confused you for this?

Thanks.

corpus.title: Extra Credit Design Problem
corpus.body: Should getMin() preserve the original order of the stack after it retrieves the min or is it okay for the stack to be arranged differently?

responses.body: getMin() only returns the min value, and should not interfere anything else. In other words, it's not okay to rearrange elements in the stack. Or it will no longer be a stack.

corpus.title: MinStack problem
corpus.body: In the MinStack bonus problem, are we allowed to use the push and pop methods that come with stacks? Or do we have to write something new

responses.body: You can use whatever you deem necessary.

corpus.title: Sudoku parameters
corpus.body: In the Sudoku project, are we allowed to pass in other parameters to the functions besides just the puzzle?

responses.body:
The short answer is no.

The long answer is:
Although the number of the parameters is fixed for the given methods, nothing stops you from simply using the given methods as wrapper methods. In other words, you can have a method underneath that tackle the critical part of the tasks and accept more parameters.

If you want to see an example, please refer to the slides on robot vacuum from Recursion.

corpus.title: Sudoku Boxes
corpus.body: Does anybody know how to make the Sudoku Boxes, or attempt to make a 3x3 box?

responses.body:
All I will say is that you can reliably believe your sudoku board matrix will not differ from it's standard of size 9 cells by 9 cells. Since you're checking a 9th of the board with every pass, perhaps you can leverage that rigid size to give you the ability to check things based on a multiplier.
Cant give you much more as it might point to a solution. Good luck!

corpus.title: lab 4 questions
corpus.body:
In case 1 of the SQueueTest file, it says to print the top element. Does this mean the "front" since it behaves like a queue, or the back, like the top of a stack. For example, if an SQueue contains 4, 5, should it print 4 or 5?

Also, why does the lab say to turn in only 3 files, but 4 are listed?

Thank you!

responses.body:
1) go with whats on top of the Queue (the last element put in), as that would probably be better practice for understanding Queues. I.e, attempt to retrieve 4 from your SQueue while maintaining the Queue itself (as in whatever modifications you do to retrieve the 4 should be undone to ensure the Queue looks the same afterward). 


2) Thats a common typo on the labs, happened it several times with the previous labs. Go with the listed files instead the number of files, that should work just fine.


Good luck

SQueue is a queue, so it should behave like a queue.

Why does the lab say to turn in only 3 files, but 4 are listed: I recently developed some difficulties in counting numbers below 10 . The Lab instruction has been updated to reflect the right number of requested submission files.

Thanks.

corpus.title: lab 4 Test class confusion
corpus.body: I am confused on how the QStackTest/Cases are supposed to be structured. How do we use that to test QStack?

responses.body: QStackTest is supposed to have a main method, and you will write three test cases under the main method (involving the initialization and declaration of a QStack you defined of course). In each test case, you will do as is in the lab instruction.
